Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Well-Defined Cyclic and Linear Poly(alpha-peptoid)s and Their Block Copolymers: Synthesis, Characterization and Solution Self-Assembly
Award.AbstractNarration: In this CAREER project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Donghui Zhang of the Louisiana State University (LSU) will carry out research to develop new polymerization methods for N-substituted-N-carboxyl anhydrides. Zhang will study the kinetics and mechanism of the ring-opening polymerization of N-substituted-N-carboxyl anhydrides mediated by nucleophilic N-heterocyclic carbenes. Various cyclic and linear block copolymers will be prepared and the types of aggregates that they form in solution will be studied. The educational plan focuses on incorporating concepts from the research project into courses at LSU and on improving LSU K-12 outreach programs, including ChemDemo and "You Be the Chemist." This work will broaden the array of biologically related polymers that scientists can use to develop new polymers and materials. Besides developing new methodologies, the proposed research will enable researchers to create biomimetic polymers that could find application in bioimaging and biomedical technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the NSF support, we investigated and developed new polymerization methods to produce a new class of biopolymers that structurally resemble proteins. We termed the new polymers as polypeptoids. We have obtained fundamental understanding on the polymerization activity, reaction kinetics and mechanism. These understanding enable us to better control the synthesis of the polymer. We also investigated how the molecular structures of the polypeptoids affect various micro and macroscopic properties (e.g., solubility, crystallinity, thermal properties and cytotoxicity) that are relevant for the further development of these polymers for various technological uses.

Graduate and undergraduate students who participated in this research received extensive training in the areas of polymer chemistry and analytic methods for characterizing polymer properties in the solution or solid phase. These training prepare them for job markets that demand abilities to think critically and work across disciplines. The PI has engaged and mentored several underrepresented minority students in the research. They have all continued on to graduate programs to pursue advanced degrees in STEM discipline. These efforts are important for the development of a diverse workforce that is well-trained and competitive in the global job market. The PI has also developed new course materials by integrating the latest research findings into lectures, which is very important for the modernization of the STEM curriculum.
